bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 25, 1940

div1.p: Hench is eager to hear more of Kean's recollections regarding his stay in Cuba and lists specific questions.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 25, 1940
div1.opener:
Y F.
June 25, 1940
General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kwan:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how much I appreciated your great patience and kindness
in letting me spend the long hours with you last week. Your information was most
helpful indeed, and by far the most authentic that I received. There were many
things that you mentioned, the significance of which I did not appreciate until after
I had left you and was thinking them over. I am going to take the liberty of writing
you again within a few days, after I have correlated my thoughts, and made some notes,
and will ask you to amplify some of the remarks which you made to me.

The two most important points that you can help me on are (1) to give me
a statement as to the information General Truby gave you regarding Lazear's experi-
mental rather than accidental yellow fever, and (2) send me in your own handwriting,
your statement as to your recollections regarding the railroad tracks behind Camp
Columbia, the little bridge over it, and the location, on the other side of the
railroad track, of the small tent hospital used to receive the victims of experimental
yellow fever after their removal from Camp Lazear. No matter how strong my language,
anything that I say you told me will not carry nearly the weight that it would if
in your own handwriting or a document signed by you, that these above statements are
correct. Rather than have you go to the bother of writing these out in long hand,
I think it would be best for me to ask you to get the services of a public stenographer.
I will write down a few questions which I should like to have answered, and then you
can answer them in just as much detail as possible. She can come to your house, take
these answers down, type them, make a copy for you, and an original and two or three
extra copies for me. You can then merely sign these pages in your own handwriting
and that will stand for all time as documentary proof. I will then have photostatic
copies of your remarks made and file them in the three or four places where they should
be filed: (1) the Army Medical Museum, (2) the Alderman Library at the University
of Virginia, (3) probably in the Historical Library at Johns Hopkins, and (4) Welch
Historical Library.

In the meantime, I cannot thank you enough for the many courtesies you showed
me, and I regret bothering you with the book which I stupidly left at your house.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
